Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Lots of stuff about current events in bioethics and health care policy, as well as past court cases
I learned a whole lot about bioethics and those topics that I didnt really know a whole lot about before
This course was an introduction to bioethics and the law and surveyed many different topics and current events.
Learned a lot about different parts of our health system and connected them to history/other fields
Overview of bioethics topics

Bioethics and Law left me with a lot of the information, background, and history on divisive issues today that will eventually allow me to take my own stance on the matters. It was a class that shed light on aspects of reality that are not talked about much yet are so important.
Learned about bioethics and law.

I learned so much throughout this course about law overall and about different bioethicial issues. I have a much deeper and more nuanced understanding of many issues now, and how they tie into everyday life.

Laws and cases surrounding the doctor-patient relationship, the duties of the doctor, health care models, research on human subjects, organ transplants, end of life care, abortion, assisted reproduction, and public health. We also learned about the basics of US government and law.
A whole field of bioethics and law that I didn't know existed! Enlightening and super pertinent to issues and decisions we will all have to deal with in our lives. A must take at Yale.
You learn basic legal stuff, which is interesting if you don't have a background in legal studies.
General knowledge on a variety of prominent bioethics issues, including history, cases, and current controversies.

I gained a deep and broad understanding of bioethics and the law. We studied abortion, organ donation, physician assisted suicide, right to die, informed consent, assisted reproduction, patents, and public health law. If any one of those topics piques your interest - take this class! I feel like I have a good understanding of each.
Good overview of Law.
Such a good class!! Was so interesting and learned a ton.

Gained a good understanding of healthcare and legislation of related issues (i.e. abortion law, human subjects testing, surrogacy contracts, physician-assisted suicide, etc...). Got good at skimming law cases and extracting info.
A lot of basic understanding of topics that I felt everyone needed to understand in order to be a better person and a better citizen.

I learned so much in this course about bioethics and law. There were so many fascinating topics that interested me. I now have a better understanding of how the law is shaped by new technologies as well as how the law is shaped by court cases and occurrences in health.
ways to articulate my opinions
History of how bioethics came to be and how tied the medical field is to law.

I learned a lot about public health law and the ethical issues associated with it. More importantly, I learned about how all of the different subsections of health and medicine (abortion, organ donation, assisted reproduction...) are intertwined through both politics, ethics and rule of law.
What a great course. I learned so much about the law in general, about bioethics, and about the world. I am pre-med, and it was awesome to learn how science interacts with legal issues and our lives.
A more robust understanding of how bioethics law works and how to use that law to predict how other events will unfold.

This course helped me gain the ability to learn in lecture, not just mindlessly writing notes. I was engaged and focused during each class meeting. I also feel that I gained a lot of knowledge on how medicine is a very cultural, social, and politically charged field.
I learned about the general concepts and legal frameworks relating to contemporary issues in bioethics.

- Got better at understanding medically-related current events

- Deepened my knowledge about the law that I already had from AP US Government in high school

- Strengthened my legal reasoning skills
Introduction to the field of bioethics and US health law.
A lot of knew knowledge about medical law, specifically history and federal cases. New skills reading and analyzing case law.
This course taught me a few fundamental skills in parsing the language of case law and picking out the most relevant parts.
I learned about the American healthcare system, the history of bioethics, and about many of the cases that define American public health law.
I learned a lot about different bioethical issues present in American society and the underlying law behind them.
Greater understanding of the law and how to study it. Really great insight into useful analytical skills
knowledge of US legal & medical & bioethics systems

In this course, I learned so much about a wide variety of topics in bioethics. These topics, such as doctor patient relationship, informed consent, end of life care, assisted reproductive technologies (and many more) are ones that I probably wouldn't have ever formally studied outside of this class, but are so relevant and applicable to our lives.
I learned a whole lot about the american legal system pertaining to medicine and health care.

I learned a great deal about the field of Bioethics and the law surrounding it because I did not know much at all before I took this course. I learned how this is an ever changing field because of the constant updates in technology and how that effects law. I also learned a lot about the United States of Americas health care systems and how the legal system works when creating laws and settling law suites and cases.
I learned about the development and characteristics of medical and public health law across a wide variety of component issues.
I learned about major controversial topics and various law concepts. This class allowed me to further understand many current issues in bioethics and their relationship with the law.
This gives a comprehensive view of bioethics and all of the relevant/popular/historic cases to understand it
I gained a lot of knowledge about current topics in bioethics and the laws surrounding them in addition to the cases that created, agreed with, or changed the laws.
I learned a lot about the medical world and approaches towards health in the U.S.

I learned a lot about bioethics law in the US and how it varies state-to-state. I learned how to analyze the legality of certain policies based on federal law and precedent established by other cases. I learned about topics like: the healthcare system, informed consent, doctor-patient relationship, research on human subjects, organ transplantation, abortion, end-of-life care, assisted reproduction, gene-editing and cloning, public health law, and global health.
I got to know more about important bioethics topics like abortion, assisted suicide, assisted reproduction, human subject research, etc.
I've gained a clearer understanding of how the American legal system and healthcare system works. I also know a lot more about specific cases that are significant to bioethics/health.

The biggest skill I learned in this course, in addition to a lot of really fascinating bioethics information, was how the US legal system works and the analysis of how to apply the law to hard, ambiguous ethical questions.

Legal analysis of bioethical topics (US healthcare system, informed consent, research on human subjects, organ donations, end of life care / right to die, abortion, assisted reproduction, patent law in the context of tech/genetic advancements, public health)
I learned basic law of US and some topics about bioethics including: Abortion, research on humans, organ donation, and reproductive rights.
I learned SO much from this class about Bioethics and Law. Every time I went to lecture, I learned so many novel and fascinating things about the medical and legal system.
I developed a lot of interesting insights from this course. Whether it was the American healthcare system or abortion rights, this class taught me material that I did not know anything about.
I have a much better understanding of the field of bioethics. I feel that I am now better equipped to discuss the current issues in the field.

I loved taking this course! This course raised many issues about the legal implications to medial disputes, and in the field of bioethics more broadly. This course encouraged me to reflect on my own standing in cases in bioethics - such as if I think physician assisted suicide or euthanasia should be allowed; should we move from an opt out to an opt in system of organ donation; and how much power the state should have over individual liberty.

I gained really clear background knowledge of (1) the U.S. healthcare system (compared to other nations), (2) the constitutional process and law, and (3) bioethics cases, their historical context, and their implications. I also improved my ability to read case law and extract/understand the important elements.

I learned a lot about law in general as well as law relating to bioethics and public health law. A lot of topics are very relevant in the modern world and I can now create more informed opinions about these topics.

Bioethics was an amazing class! It was so interesting to hear how current ideas and laws surrounding new medical technology, and how it came to be. It was also interesting to learn about the American political system, the American healthcare system and how they came together at different points throughout history. It taught me how to read and understand court cases, and the power of each president set. Overall this was an incredibly interesting class and a great introduction to the American Law.
bioethics

A thorough survey of all important topics in bioethics, historical and contemporary. In particular, we discussed the American healthcare system, doctor-patient relationships, research on human subjects, organ donation, abortion, end-of-life care, and biotechnology.

This class makes you think about bioethical issues and about how the law influences bioethics, for better or worse. As Professor Latham said in his final lecture, this class makes you a better newspaper reader  it gives you the tools to think about bioethics and law from a positive and normative perspective.
A lot of thinking about the intricacies of bioethics law and how complicating the issues can become.

This is a fantastic survey course in all issues bioethics. Even if I don't necessarily go into a field where I need these skills, I think I learned a lot of useful information to navigate through the medical system in the future.
How to think about cases about morality.
I learned about the American healthcare system, insurance, as well as countless more and legal issues facing the American society at large.
I learned so much about bioethics law and different constitutional rights that I did not know prior to taking this course. Great course.
Law and bioethics

I learned a lot about the ethical dilemmas that come up in the field of biology, most of which I had never thought much about like genetic control, human testing, and organ donation laws. This is a really thought provoking course without being inaccessibly academic.

How to discuss bioethical topics and questions
How to think about political/ethical issues
Learned a lot about topics about the controversies and issues about the American healthcare system and bioethical issues related to it.
I learned basic knowledge about the American health care system and about the way in which the American (and other) governments seek to remedy and regulate complex bioethics issues.

I learned so, so, SO many interesting current issues in bioethics and politics. I'm so glad I can be well informed about controversial issues like abortion and end of life not only for discussing with others but also if they are ever relevant to my own life.
I learned SO much in this class about how the American healthcare system works and how the legal system works with respect to ethical issues.

This class was an introductory course on bioethics and law. The focus was primarily on the legal frameworks in place in the U.S. that handle bioethics, however at times we also discussed how they compared to legal frameworks outside of the U.S.  It covered a variety of topics, ranging from end of life, human subjects research, abortion, STEM cell research and assisted suicide. In addition to developing a wide range of knowledge in topics in bioethics and law, the reading in this class also helps you get used to reading literature on legal cases, and you learn more about how the legal system works in the U.S.
I learned a lot about the law and how to read and understand cases. I also learned a lot about health-related topics and feel like I got a great overview on a variety of different fronts.
Learned how to think about policy decisions in a specific field (bioethics) and the framework that governs legal decisions
Learned basics of the law, specifically with regards to bioethics. Also became better at taking notes and learning during a lecture.

I learned about many different topics in bioethics from their origin, through history, until present day. I also learned about many legal principles that I was unfamiliar with before taking the class, and many of the Supreme Court cases related to bioethics issues.
I learned a lot about issues of bioethics, but more so, felt I gained a much larger understanding of the American legal and healthcare systems.
I learned about the field of bioethics, important legal cases (state and federal level) that were vital in setting bioethics precedent, and law history.
This class really helped me better think about the questions that I may have to answer for myself in the future, such as end of life care and artificial reproduction techniques.
Bioethics is actually a really interesting concept, and more relevant to our lives than one would think of before learning about these topics.
I learned so much about the field of bioethics-- about which I knew very little going into the course. It was so engaging and interesting.

We learned about a really wide variety of topics in bioethics including healthcare, organ transplantation, abortion, cloning, assisted reproduction, patenting of living organisms, and many other things.
I learnt a lot about American Healthcare system and bioethics issues.

I learned about some of the most important concepts in bioethics and how those concepts are understood and considered in the context of the U.S. justice system.  More broadly, I learned to notice similarities and differences in arguments (legal and otherwise) and to apply those arguments across concepts.
S O MUCH. It was my first bioethics course and I really loved it.
I learned a lot about public heath law and bioethics. It taught what it was supposed to teach. I also regained the ability to write a comprehensive and coherent essay in 20 min.
This was one of my favorite classes. Take it.

I learned just how controversial the field of medicine can be legally and how laws have been made to make decisions i tricky situations. Most topics weren't black or white but lied in a gray area that sparked many conversations in section weekly.
Much better understanding on how law works and the use of precedents. Also how precedents change over time.
Bioethics was really cool and we learned all about cases and law.
understanding bioethical issues  not just morally but legally
I can't say I learned a whole lot from this class. Most of it felt like a general rehash of things I already knew about the law or about the medical profession.
I learned about Bioethics and Law and about various topics pertaining to it.
I learned to think about the intersection of the medical field and the legal one. The course focused on how laws are constantly changing to adapt to new technologies.
Awesome class thoroughly loved it highly recommend
I gained understanding about the American healthcare and medical system, and learned about the basics of legal reasoning.

Learned a ton about the law through the specific lens of Bioethics, and the American Healthcare system. So much of the information learned about assisted reproduction, end-of-life care, abortion, research on human subjects, public health, organ donation, informed consent, medical malpractice, patent law, and physician-assisted suicide was interesting, engaging, and in some way or another relatable. This class showed me how so much of bioethics law differs from state to state. Some fields like assisted reproduction are almost entirely unregulated as contrasted with abortion law, which is extremely variable. I learned how to use cases as evidence in building an argument for why a given new law is unconstitutional. This class taught me that sometimes questions in the bioethics field are really really difficult, and sometimes moral judgments and legal judgments do not align.
Great intro to the filed of bioethics!
This course was extremely useful, as it educated me on the fundamentals of law as well as the intersection between law, research, and medicine.
I gained an understanding of the American health care system and its history, often in comparison to the health care systems of other nations.
I gained insight into the intersection of the legal world and the medical world and was able to apply prior knowledge to new cases and scenarios.
an understanding of how ethics works in the US legal system. I gained knowledge on important topics like abortion, assisted reproduction, human subjects research, etc.
I gained a lot of insight into the basics of the American legal system. I also learned how to read legal cases, and gained an understanding on controversial issues in bioethics.
Learned about different issues in bioethics and between doctors and patients.
By taking this course, I learned the foundations of bioethics, and the role that law plays in this area. These topics include court cases on abortion, assisted reproduction, right to die, and so on.
An intro to a field which many people hear about, but never really study in-depth.

This being the first law class I have taken, I learned much in terms of the workings of the American legal system and how to reason through different scenarios based on bast rulings. I also finished this class with a much more thorough understanding of the many areas of bioethics which we discussed.
Learned about the overlap between ethics and the laws that govern ethics.
Great overview of bioethics.

I learned a lot about significant cases in U.S. history that shape the laws governing today, as well as many ways in which the states differ from one another in statutes and the ways in which U.S. holdings differ from the rest of the world.
This was a great introduction to a lot of modern topics in bioethics.
I learned about the law surrounding medical practices in the United States and in the World.

I learned so much about the intersection of law and medicine. In all honesty I knew very little about most of the subjects we covered in this class - from doctor patient relationships and organ transplants, to right to die and public health law. As a result, I learned a great deal of not only really interesting but really important information!
I developed the ability to analyze the legal and ethical facets of certain bioethics topics
Important cases and controversies in the medical world and in public health.
I gained a comprehensive knowledge of medical law in the United States, as well as the ethical background for this law.
I learned about how to think about health issues in the context of the U.S. Constitution and Supreme Court cases.
I learned different types of bioethics issues and the different aspects of family, medical care, and moral values that are evaluated while making decisions for these issues.
LOVED THIS CLASS! Learned so much about law!
I learned more about our bioethics in the world and about course cases which are very important to our daily lives.

Fundamentals of the U.S. legal and healthcare systems and how law is applied in areas of medicine and bioethics.  Feel comfortable with important cases in U.S. law and how they affect future decisions about new medicine and technologies.
I learned about the relationship between medicine and law.
This course is an amazing overview of the american legal and health care systems with a deep dive into important bioethical issues. No prior knowledge of any of these topics is necessary.
This course gives students an incredible overview of medical policies, landmark court cases, and just general info about how health in the US works as a system.
interesting stuff

I learned so much about various bioethics topics that are very relevant today, as well as how to read and analyze legal cases. I think the best part of the class was realizing how personal and real the topics were (such as end-of-life care, informed consent, etc.) and I feel much more equipped to talk about the current events in bioethics that I see on the news every day.
I learned about the american healthcare system and the relationship between bioethics and american law.
LOVED THIS COURSE. I didn't have any prior knowledge of bioethics, so interesting.
I learned more about issues in bioethics.

Excellent way to hone analytical skills as well as debate bioethical issues both from a legal and moral standpoint. Focus on examining law was particularly helpful for all those contemplating law school in the future.

This class introduced me to general topics in the field of bioethics -- we didn't go very in-depth into any subject (or any specific legal case), but we learned enough to talk about them and connect them thematically to one another.
I learned so much about how the court system views issues like brain death, organ transplantation, stem cell research, assisted reproduction, and public health.

This course introduced me to the complex and incredibly interesting laws that govern the medical field.  We covered the basics of different healthcare systems, medical malpractice law, abortion regulation, end of life care, organ donation, as well as domestic and international public health.  The most interesting topics by far were abortion, end of life care, and organ donation (these are what Professor Latham most emphasizes).  And for all of these topics, we briefly went over the historical context behind the laws, the landmark Supreme Court cases, and how the laws changed over time (for example, we covered Griswold v CT, Roe v Wade, and then Planned Parenthood v Casey for abortion).  But more than anything, I learned about the different medical legal rights that people have and how we came to have those rights (think having doctor assisted suicide as an option for end of life care).
I learned a great deal about bioethics and law and the overall American medical system.
A greater understanding of both how the law deals with progressing medical technological advances and the ethical issues that are causing the most debate in the medical community

I learned about how the medical field and it's developments fits into the larger picture of society, and allowed me to understand how medicine affects everyone and how it's relevance shapes both public policy and the lives of people.
Much better understanding of how culture and politics have changed with new medical technology and techniques as well as how to develop my own ideas and argue them.
I learned the history of bio ethics along with current events
I learned so much about certain areas of bioethics, knowledge that I won't easily forget.
I gained a comprehensive knowledge of bioethics law. I think this is helpful for my future and present interactions with my medical care and the care of people I care about.

This was a very interesting course overall. I feel like I learned about a variety of interesting/controversial topics that I knew vaguely about before. It was great to learn the history, law(s), and contemporary debates.
Evaluating ethical situations using law and reasoning.
More nuanced understanding of the legal system and just how...law even works!

I learned a huge amount about American and international healthcare systems, health and medical law, and medical ethics. I think it will be great information to have, as a human being navigating through healthcare systems.
I learned about the major issues in bioethics, as well as a good amount of historical knowledge about the development of the medical profession in conjunction with new technologies.
I learned very practical, useful knowledge about issues in bioethics, enlightening things about abortion, assisted reproduction, organ donation, etc. from the coolest guy ever.
We learned the basic workings of the US government, current issues in bioethics and law, and the historical context behind them.

I learned more about the subject of bioethics, of consent/working with human subjects, how to ensure the protection of vulnerable populations, and more about the ethics behind hot-button bioethics issues (abortion, assisted suicide/euthanasia, organ donation).
It was a very interesting and engaging class. Many bioethic related issues were presented and discussed.
I loved every bit of this course. Lectures dragged a little
Very interesting subject. I wish professor Latham posted notes or something of the lecture since it can be hard to get all the necessary information written down when he is just talking
This course was a very interesting. Lecture was informative and a wonderful opportunity to hear all of Professor Latham's insights and discussion section was a time to share opinions and discuss.

Strengths: very interesting, not too challenging, professor Latham is very good at teaching the information clearly and he makes it very interesting
Weakness: The grading rule was very unfair. He only allowed 2 people in each section to get an A, which made the grading based more on what the TF thought and less on how well you actually knew the information.
Engaging lectures, tough grading that I felt like killed my joy for the class
The course covers very interesting and relevant topics. It is fantastic!

Lectures were great and so fascinating. Professor Latham so engaging. I think he could have emphasized which readings to focus most on for exams, as the readings were extensive. Also, I had no legal background so maybe an introduction to how to read legal cases would be helpful.
Overall this was a really great course that highlighted a lot of difficult issues in an engaging and informative way. The lectures were really amazing, and went over the material well.
Great lecture. Love Latham.
Very interesting material.
Strengths include scope of material and relevance of issues brought up

This course introduces complex legal issues in a student-friendly manner. All of main take-aways were extremely accessible. Latham is an incredible lecturer and if you take good notes then you are set. I honestly can not think of any weaknesses. I loved this course.
Great lectures. Sometimes Professor Latham starts to run down a rabbit hole where we get off-topic in lecture, but for the most part it's good stuff.
lectures were very clear and interesting.
Honestly, I'm very happy with it. Section is actually useful. Classes are taught well, Latham also goes over the previous lecture's material so the information really sticks with you.
The strength of this course was how interesting the topics were, as well as how Professor Latham was able to keep everyone's attention throughout the duration of the class.
great professor
None, its a great class

Strengths: LATHAM! He was an incredible professor. The discussion sections were also a strength of this class because they allowed us to talk in smaller groups about the controversial subjects from class on a deeper, more intimate level. 

Weaknesses: Honestly, this was my favorite class this semester. No changes

The only weakness of this course is that Professor Latham sometimes does not name cases in his lectures, so you have to go look them up after to see what he was referring to. The final is also worth a hefty portion of the grade. However, it is overall really interesting, well taught, and well organized.
IT is PERFECT.

I love that Professor Latham does not use a PowerPoint presentation. Because he simply lectures, I am forced to listen and engage with the lecture instead of simply mindlessly copying a PowerPoint. Although, because of lack of a visual lecture supplement, I often miss important names, such as case names. Maybe writing them on the board would be beneficial.

I enjoyed the course because the material was fascinating, and there was not much unnecessary work that did not facilitate further insight into the subject matter. 
I was hoping the course would explore the arguments -- legal and ethical -- on both sides of the issues instead of merely laying out an overview of what the issues are. It seemed like we learned a lot of realities regarding topics in bioethics but not many reasons for them or for alternatives. The course relies a lot on substantive due process and takes it as a given, but I think more attention should be given to its shortcomings and the legal reasoning for/against it.

There's really nothing I can say about this class that hasn't been said before. Latham is an incredible lecturer, the material is fascinating, the workload is minimal, and the grading is fair. I wouldn't have minded if the class was more work (perhaps some written assignments) for further engagement with the material.

Strengths:
- Interesting
- Section is useful
- Well-structured view of the field of bioethics

Weaknesses:
- Not very rigorous, though I'd imagine that that's by design
- Not very in-depth at all

Interesting material, engaging lectures, good book. Lectures occasionally repetitive, however, and sometimes felt oversimplified (rarely exploring the more contentious sides of these topics and exploring counterarguments). I felt that section could have been more interesting, considering the intensity of the topics, but was often a re-hashing of the main lecture takeaways. Also supplemental readings usually felt superfluous.
The strength of this course is absolutely the content, which is fascinating and well-developed, but the readings made this class homework difficult.
I thought the course was very strong. My only suggestion is that all TA's are screened more before teaching. My roommate had a TA that was very bad, which made the course much worse for her.
Less reading and make it more selected so that people can engage with the readings, etc.
strengths: Latham is a great lecturer, and the subject matter is very useful. weaknesses: section wasn't super useful.

This was by far my favorite class I took this year. I think that the way Professor Latham broke the course down, spending two or three classes on each topic, was a really effective way to teach. The material was extremely interesting and always kept me engaged.
The lectures were fantastic. I wish more people participated in section and that we could have debated topics.

I think this class did a good job of teaching us how the legal system and health care systems work in America before teaching us about Bioethics so that we understood how things worked, prior to getting too in depth with the cases. I also think the cases were introduced and taught well.

Professor Latham's lectures were always very interesting, and I learned a ton each class. Sections could have tied in material outside the casebook (from Canvas) more, but overall the class was enjoyable and educational.
Weakness- you dont really know why the TFs give you a particular grade on exams

The strengths of this course are definitely the lectures. I consistently looked forward to coming to lectures. Some of the readings are dense, but that is to be expected since we have to read law cases.
I loved how the course is organized and all the material it covers. I can't find anything bad to say about this course.

I thought the course was super interesting, and Professor Latham was a very good lecturer. I wished that the discussion sections for the class relied more on objective evidence from the readings and from class, instead of people's opinions. I also thought the grading was a little confusing, and I wish they had clarified what exactly they were looking for on the midterms and final.
Strengths: Lectures were very thorough and inclusive of all course material. Section was engaging and fun.Course material was very informative and interesting.

Latham is a great lecturer and clearly passionate about the subject. Lectures are really interesting, as we learn a lot about controversies with bioethics issues that you see a lot in the news/are applicable to our daily lives (e.g. abortion, surrogacy). Weakness is that grading seems fairly arbitrary across different TAs. Sometimes, one omitted detail on one essay question brings you down from an A to an A-.

Professor Lathams lectures are FANTASTIC. I was engaged and enthralled during every single lecture. TAs really make or break a course, though. I would also have liked formal review sessions before the final and midterms.
Incredible lecturer in Stephen Latham. Very interesting material. Also, because it is a law class, your TA is likely going to be a law student, and those are by far the best TAs.

The class is a huge lecture course and only has three assignments, tests. The tests seem to be graded arbitrarily and no amount of studying can fix it. You just have to kind of write an essay, but not really an essay in 25 minutes and just expect them to like what you wrote and how you did. I dont really know how you can work and put in effort to get a decent grade. But hey theres no homework!
This course was perfect and I just wish I had more time because I would want to learn even more!
The lectures were very interesting and I enjoyed learning about all the elements in American bioethics. There were a lot of different topics but they were all very interesting.
Professor Latham is a very engaging lecturer. It is a great course. However, I wish I had received better feedback on my midterms.

Strength: Professor Latham was amazing. His lectures were so engaging, and extremely easy to follow. This was easily the best class I have taken at Yale, and I truly looked forward to class. 

Weakness: I wish there were more classes like this at Yale!

Professor Latham is excellent. He presents all of the information in a very organized, cohesive, and clear narrative/manner, which makes learning the material so much easier. I think the test-taking process is great in terms of (1) the amount of material we're responsible for and (2) the amount of time we're allotted to answer the questions. I also really liked the sectionsI think we spent the perfect amount of time reviewing the material vs. debating/discussing the material. Everyone was incredibly respectful in my section, especially with sensitive topics, and contributed to the conversation!

I thought the lectures were incredible! The readings were also very interesting. As far as midterms, I thought the first one was incredibly unfair because it required knowledge of law regarding book-sellers, which was not covered in the course. Even if they did not grade on what we talked about with the book-sellers, it was hard to write comparisons to doctors when I knew nothing to compare to. I studied a lot but could not show what I learned due to the nature of the question.

This was a really great class. Professor Latham broke the class up into several sections, each of which were easy to follow and made chronological sense. Sections also complimented lecture, and we learned about the core concepts, and then had the space to ask questions, discuss and share our thoughts. Overall the class was well constructed, and there was always a place to ask questions.

Honestly, everything about this class was good except for the EXAMS. If you're not good at regurgitating massive amounts of information in the form of two essays in 50 minutes, I'm sorry but you WILL struggle in this class, because I was in that exact place this semester. The TAs grade on an unforgiving curve (20% As, 20% A-s, etc.) in a class where the majority of the students have a good grasp on the content (since it's not conceptually difficult to understand). In practice, what that ends up meaning is that there are students who have a fairly good grasp on the content who consistently get B+s on the exams because they forgot to mention a couple things here and there in their exam, whereas other students do well by filling up entire bluebooks with every word that came out of Professor Latham's mouth over the course of the semester. I am of the opinion that the type of "learning" this testing style encourages is neither valuable nor fair. Hopefully, something will be done to at least balance out the heavy emphasis on fact regurgitation in this class (e.g. by having one midterm and one paper for the class rather than 2 midterms). All that aside, though, Professor Latham was a great lecturer and the TAs were super nice and fun to be around. I would just personally recommend you take this class Credit/D/Fail if you can, as the grading could be quite frustrating at times.

The class was well organized and interesting, but at times felt a little repetitive. I liked that there weren't any lecture slides used in the class, it kept me focused and the professor was great at drawing in relevant, contemporary case examples of what he was talking about.
engaging and lots to learn
A great course overall, and well-loved by many students. Very few improvements to make.

The main weakness is the lack of lecture slides or class notes, which means you are entirely dependent on your own lecture notes. If you miss something, it's sort of lost forever (unless you ask someone else, of course). 
Otherwise, the course is fascinating no matter what your major is because the themes in bioethics and law will inevitably show up in everyone's life.
This class was really interesting.
Stephen Latham is fantastic and he provides some really interesting readings if you care to read them.

There are not any notes or powerpoints so the content you know is solely based on the notes you take in class, which is from what he says in lecture. He was very clear in what he wanted us to take out of every lecture and the content was interesting. It was a really amazing class.

The course is extremely comprehensive and manages to cover lots of complicated material very quickly and with relative ease of understanding. I wish section had been a little more engaging, but otherwise I think the course was very well taught.
The course was very well structured. Professor Latham is engaging and the cases are so interesting.
Perfect

This course has excellent lectures-- Professor Latham is a funny, interesting guy who knows how to work a crowd. He could always come up with something engaging to say no matter what subject we were on, and he really made the field feel exciting.

Stephan Latham is an excellent lecturer and the topics are extremely interesting and focus on controversial aspects of American healthcare and bioethics. Sections are very boring however and don't really add any value to the class. Weekly reading responses are a plus but TAs can really impact how much you like the class which sometimes they unfortunately fail to do.

I thought the course material was very interesting and Stephen Latham is a very charismatic lecturer. However, sometimes I felt like the lectures weren't terribly engaging and I didn't feel like the reading was relevant to the course.

Overall nothing but strengths. One weakness is that during the second exam, I was sitting at the top and the entire row of boys sitting behind me were cheating and discussing answers. It was so disrespectful and distracting trying to tune them out so I could focus on my exam. I don't know how the many TFs didn't notice anything :/ But anyways, great course where I learned a lot and loved Prof. Latham's engaging teaching style. I also think I lucked out with my section, though I do wish there was some standardization across them. For example, I compared what my TF wanted in response to a "is this constitutional" question on the final vs. my friend's TF and they were rather different.
Professor Lathem is a very engaging lecturer and I do not have any suggestions for improvements in this class.

Overall, I thought this was a very good course.  The lectures were clear, engaging, easy to follow and extremely interesting.  The exams were very fair and reasonable, and the weekly reading response was also quite simple.  The weakest part of my experience was the weekly section.  I often felt like my section was overwhelmed by what one or two students had to say, and my TA did not know how to guide the discussion to prevent that from happening.

My favorite part of the class was the lectures. I always found them incredibly interesting and engaging. I would often not realize that 50 minutes had gone by and suddenly class was over. Professor Latham does a great job, and I looked forward to going to the lectures each week. I'd say something that could be improved slightly is just the fact that the readings really aren't necessary to do well in sections or the midterms/final. I think finding a way to tie the readings into the class a bit more and making sure people are doing the readings would be useful.
Professor Latham is great. Lectures were very engaging. Section was helpful. One of my favorite courses at Yale.

Reading certain areas of the textbook that corresponded to the information learned in class should have been emphasized more. I felt that if I did not go to lecture, I would have nothing to study or learn from for tests.

Strengths: The topics were extremely interesting (organ transplantation, end of life care, abortion, intellectual property, healthcare systems, global health) and ones that I have heard surface-level information about before, but never really dove into or understood until this class. I really enjoyed every lecture, which was taught in the manner of a story from historical origins until present day.

Weaknesses: I would have preferred that there were more assignments, and that reading assignments counted for participation grade (instead of our entire grade riding on the three exams).
Interesting information, I wish the exams felt slightly less pedantic.
This was a very interesting course and Latham was a wonderful lecturer. I do wish we had the chance to write an essay so our midterms and finals were not weighted so heavily.

This class goes over some very interesting topics that are going to be fascinating as society continues to make advances in biology and medicine. I would like to see more time spent on patenting biological materials/organisms as well as assisted reproduction (basically the last part of the course). Perhaps that would be better suited as a completely different course.
The lectures are organized very well. The grading for mid-terms is really unclear because our TA never gave us feedback on why we got the grades we did and our booklets had no feedback on them.

Strengths- so interesting and engaging, amazing lectures, great explanations of topics and cultural relevance 
Weaknesses- more explanation of what is expected on tests

Lectures are awesome and Latham is incredibly engaging and intelligent. I think there is just too much dependent on the TAs and how they grade. It seems that Latham tried to introduce a rigid template to help guide their grading, yet there were still major discrepancies between the sections.
I think the class is pretty great as it is.
The grading is terrible. The final carries too much weight which is not good.

Strengths:  Professor Latham's lectures were amazing.  They were well-organized, thoughtful, and full of information.  I also thought that the course covered a good range of material.  I feel much more capable of following and participating in discussions about anything from abortion to stem cell research in a nuanced way.
Weaknesses:  Honestly, I wish that the course covered even more, and that discussion section debates were more interesting.  I felt like we learned enough to learn that we didn't know enough.  There were times when I felt that I wanted to make a particular argument, only to find that I didn't have the knowledge to do so.  I felt like my TF wanted us to challenge some of the claims Professor Latham presented, particularly historical interpretations of the Constitution (such as the privacy/due process argument concerning the Fourteenth Amendment), but we just didn't have the capacity to do so in an actually original and interesting way.  I think that if the course covered topics in some more depth, particularly providing some information (either though readings or in the lecture) about how to make ethical and legal arguments, these discussions could have been more interesting.  I also wish that exams were more straightforward.  The first midterm, in particular, I felt asked certain questions implicitly that could have just been asked explicitly.  It was often hard to know what answer was being sought, and it wasn't really the point of the exam to have us guess -- it was more to have us just to explain what we knew.
overall i think it was great.
There isnt homework which is great, but it means learning is all up to the student. It makes it a very self-driven course which could be a strength or a weakness.
This class is amazing. Professor Latham is amazing.

Strengths: STEPHEN LATHAM IS A STAR. Not only is he the foremost in his field, but also super engaging. He's such a great lecturer and understands how to structure class in a way that is interesting and conducive to note-taking. 
Weaknesses: Grading can be a bit subjective depending on your TA.
The course is excellent! It covers so many interesting topics and the material builds on itself making it easy for students to follow along. I don't think this course needs any improvement.
Great professor

It was really interesting and the workload was completely manageable. That's a hard combination to find. The lectures and section were really engaging and I always found it easy to participate in section.
Really great course and the professor was great.
writing skills and analytical skills could be improved

This course kind of feels all over the place. Professor Latham is a remarkably compelling lecturer. Other than that, though, I feel like there isn't much going on in the class. Some of this might come from the fact that I took this course Credit/D and wasn't paying that much attention. However, I felt as though I didn't really need to show up to class in order to do well on the exams and understand the material. From speaking to other students, it seems as though a lot of the richness of the class came from the course readings. However, considering that exams only covered materials from lecture and my section leader never had us discuss the reading materials, I never felt incentivized to do any of the readings. I think this course could be improved by incentivizing the reading materials. Also, Latham could easily move at a faster pace within lectures and dive into more material without the class becoming in any way burdensome. A lot of lecture was spent rehashing and reviewing. Sometimes Latham would talk about current events  that didn't feel particularly relevant to the course material. By streamlining lectures and going more in depth, the class could be really compelling and intellectually challenging.
Professor Latham is a great lecturer and made class interesting. The discussion sections were also engaging.

Strengths: excellent lectures, interesting section discussions, content felt relevant 
Weaknesses: grading (at times), lot of material
This course is super interesting, which makes it easy!
This course was strong in its organization and coverage of major bioethics concepts. It had an excellent balance of narrative case studies and broader legal issues.

Strengths:
1. Lecture is super interesting. Professor Latham is a great lecturer. Go to class!
2. Section is fun
3. For how niche bioethics is, its very applicable to daily life and the conversation often carried over into lunch after class

Weaknesses:
1. No grades except the 2 midterms (25% each) and the final (50%), all essay form in class. Its extremely hard to write two good essays in 50 minutes. Sometimes I thought the questions asked on the midterm made a leap from what 
2. Grading depends on your TA, and grading of midterms is generally slow (2 weeks)
3. I wish the reading responses were graded! It felt so weird to hand in assignments that werent graded at all, and attributing 10% to the reading responses and 40% to the final would have felt more comfortable. 
4. Not much incentive to do the readings. We only talked about a few cases in which we had to read the casebook for, but Prof. Latham posts a lot of articles that supplement the information from lecture that not many people read because it is not directly tested.
This course would benefit from more frequent office hours.
I think it was very engaging and informative. However, I sometimes felt a disconnect between section material and discussions and lectures, which I think could be improved.
Less textbook reading or a more consolidated case list would improve the course.

strengths- great prof, so interesting
weakness- really biased TF's. Inconsistencies in the grading.

PLEASE READ:

Sections are incredibly variant in terms of rigor and quality. While some sections are quite thorough in the coverage of lecture, the others tended to be more abstract. The issue with this system is that the level of preparation is not reflected in the actual grading. I could have an 'easier TA' (not to make fun of her, but Samantha Goodwin would be a good example) and do better on the midterms than with a 'harder TA' (not to make fun of him at all because he is a great TA, but Travis Pantin) with the same amount of preparation. It's unfair.

The highlight of this course was definitely the lectures, which were very well-taught. Professor Latham is a great professor, and lecture was always engaging and insightful. I thought this was a very fair course in terms of its grading and structure as well.

Strengths: good lecturer, format of the class seems fair. The faculty were all very transparent about the material that was necessary to study and the type of answers they were looking for on the exams.

For the most part, what you get out of this class is proportional to the effort that you put in. Attending lecture, completing the readings both in the book and online, and participating in discussion sections all proved to be extremely interesting and fruitful. Further, it was not difficult to learn a lot, understand the material well, and succeed in the class if you put an effort into each of those areas.
Fantastic lectures. Textbook did not follow the class.

This course was fantastic. The only weakness would be that the grading system is very odd because there are only three grades and only letter grades are given, so there is no way to really understand where you stand in the class or numerically evaluate your performance on the tests. It can also be hard to identify why you got a certain grade for that reason. I would also maybe recommend providing slides of some kind (not because Professor Latham needs them--just for the benefit of the students).
Very amazing course. No complaints
None!
The lecture information was clear and interesting. It would have been more helpful if we focused on tying things back to larger themes in the course
This course was great, I learned a lot.
Strengths include the interest of the subject. Weaknesses include low engagement.
I think that the course is very good the way it is.
it was incredible do not change it
The strengths of this course is that the information was very relevant and interesting and I really enjoyed going into class everyday.
This course was very well organized to promote learning and engage my interest.  I liked how sections were not graded but could help your grade.
I enjoyed this course very much. I wish we had sobered more topics and done a bit less background at the beginning.
This course was super interesting and moved at a great pace. The topics were diverse, fascinating and relevant.
This class is amazing. Professor Lathams lectures were always interesting and kept me engaged during every unit.
nothing

I thought this class was very well taught (Latham is an amazing lecturer) and the topics were well-chosen. I found myself excited and engaged during every lecture because the topics were just so interesting and fresh. However, I wish I had gotten more feedback after my exams.
Great lecture, no improvements.  Maybe uploaded slides or something.
I thought this course was great. I was really interesting and fun to attend.

I wanted more assignments, if only so that the final wouldn't be worth so much. Why no papers? Professor Latham said he hoped the class would make us better voters and readers of newspapers--in that vein, we could have had a paper evaluating recent developments in bioethics and connecting them to previous cases/histories.

Professor Latham is a superb lecturer: captivating, reflective, and intellectually curious. Absolutely no qualms with the lectures. On the other hand, sections were somewhat painful, with many not contributing and TAs not necessarily knowing how to facilitate class discussion. Grading seemed opaque and subjective. There definitely needs to be more standardization and care when training TAs. Below, I noted that I am neutral on whether the course facilitated student learning. I selected this option as I think the lectures absolutely did, but sections really fell short.
Very well taught, interesting lectures and Prof Latham was very engaging and organized

This is a very typical lecture course in that you are completely responsible for how you perform in the course and for how much you get out of it -- there is absolutely nothing and no one holding you accountable.   I never did the readings (I dont think many people did) and honestly, it would have been a waste of time.  While the casebook is great and very interesting, there are quite a few readings assigned and it is not necessary to do them since the lecture covers everything that you need to know. Additionally, Professor Latham only wants you to know the really important Supreme Court cases which he will name in class (if he does not name them, you can always google them later).  Section is also very laidback and the background knowledge you need for it will be covered in lecture.  Another thing is that there is no way to know how you are doing in the course until you get back your midterm scores.  Perhaps having the weekly reading responses graded or getting some feedback on them would be helpful (and would cut away at the huge 50% that the final counts for).  And finally, having more practice questions distributed before tests would be extremely helpful as we walked into midterms barely knowing what the questions would be like.
The course is taught very well and it is very interesting.

It was a really great course, and I don't really have any feedback for the course except perhaps putting lecture notes online if one must miss a class. But, there are many strengths to the course, and it was a very engaging and well taught course.
Great lectures and structure for sections; however, the material can be repetitive at times.
Strengths the lectures were engaging
The lectures are great. However, there shouldn't be so much reading assigned  it should be specific to the cases we talk about in class. Also sections should count for participation.
One thing that could be improved would be to make more than three gradepoints that make up the final grade such as essays for sections.
The topics are overall very interesting. Latham is an amazing lecturer. I also enjoyed our section discussions. This is a solid course.

Strengths: Taught us how to use existing law to back up our arguments.
Weaknesses: Few opportunities for grading outside the three major exams.

Lectures are suuuuper interesting, I look forward to going. Readings sometimes feel excessive. Grading can feel a little unfair and arbitrary. Different TFs grade differently, and it's super ambiguous what Prof Latham likes in an essay. Certain 'key phrases' get you necessary points, certain ones get you bonus points, and others don't really make a difference? Hard to tell what you need to do for an A as opposed to a B+.

I loved the lectures, which were incredibly interesting, and my sections were also very interesting, if not the most engaging sections I have ever participated in. My only real complaint about the course, is that the format does not induce investment and engagement with the material. I wish that there had been a project or a paper that would have required some amount of engagement with the readings, or at least encouraged critical thinking and discussions. Other than that, I thought it was quite thought-provoking.

Professor Latham is an excellent and engaging lecturer. The subject matter was interesting and relevant. The main weakness of the course is that I found the midterms to be rather harshly graded. It seems that what was asked of the students was a brain dump on the page rather than a thoughtful analysis. I would prefer for future midterms to focus more on legal analysis rather than regurgitation of facts.

I found the course material of Bioethics so interesting, and Professor Latham is a pretty engaging lecturer.  I always looked forward to going to class.  I also really appreciate that now I feel much more prepared to discuss issues that are being brought up worldwide currently.  There is not much work involved with this class, and the supplemental readings can be pretty interesting.  It also is not too time-consuming to prepare for the exams.

I think this course was well-structured in the sense that it was not repetitive, but rather, it continued to expand on previously discussed topics as the course progressed.  All of the information was relevant, interesting, timely, and well-presented.
Great class was well structured and organized. I thought it was great how the class was broken down in regards to tests and how the class was taught.
If you're at all interested in health care policy and controversy, yes!
Yes. It is super interesting
I would absolutely recommend this course. It was both interesting and engaging and extremely relevant. Take it!!!
Yes!! amazing class, and now I want to take more classes on bioethics.
Yes but it is not a gut as some say. Easy B+, hard A.
Yes!
Absolutely. The issues are very topical, it was incredibly interesting, and Professor Latham was great.

Yes definitely because it was a really interesting course that has relevance to literally anyone's life. It's made me a more informed person, and a lot of the issues are important in society/politics today. It was also just a cool course.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anybody. I'd never had any exposure to law and really appreciated getting a better general sense of our legal system. The material we covered is relevant to everyone's own lives (e.g. doctor-patient relationships, rights to privacy, etc.) and to current events (e.g. abortion law, public health law, etc.). The testing is fair and straightforward and I really feel like I've come away with a great deal of knowledge without having to be stressed out by the course.
Yes
Yes. Enlightening and super pertinent to issues and decisions we will all have to deal with in our lives. A must take at Yale.
Good class but not the easy A it's made out to be.
Absolutely! It serves as an interesting way to learn a little about healthcare, medicine, law, and ethics.
Take it. You won't regret it.
Great course! A lot of interesting issues and discussions

I've wanted to take this class since my first-year at Yale (I'm a junior now), and I am SO happy that I had a chance to this semester. Wow - this class was great. I learned so much and enjoyed learning it all. This is a highly recommended class, from what I understand, and for good reason. It is not necessarily an easy A, but you will like studying so much that it will feel like an easy A. Take it!
Yes. Latham is awesome, and the material is super interesting.

Yes- very interesting. I never woke up to be so excited for a morning (10:30 am) class! Professor Latham is very clear and nice. Grading was slightly ambiguous as numerical grades weren't assigned and it seemed to heavily depend on which TA you get. Thus, it's a good class to start off taking cred/d/f and see how you do on the first two midterms before keeping/changing grade mode.
Yes! Loved it.

Highly recommend. Very interesting topics, not much work on the weekly. Exams are more than fair and easy to prepare for. For best results, take this class with a group of friends, it'll make section and studying actually fun.
I would absolutely recommend this class to another student because of how interesting it was.
yes
I would definitely recommend, especially Credit/D.

Absolutely. This course was my favorite this semester. It really helped me to understand and decipher what my own beliefs were on such controversial subjects. Everything was relevant to current time and was incredibly interesting.
Yes! Take this course while you are here. I know it has a reputation as a "gut" but it is honestly a gem. I was sad when I had to miss lecture once, and I wasn't even taking it for a grade!

If Professor Latham taught a class on how paint dries, I would take it; this man could lecture about anything and make it seem like the most interesting, most important thing in the world. TAKE HIS CLASSES.

Absolutely. Professor Latham is an amazing lecturer and the course material is very interesting. The material is also something that everyone should learn because everyone, someway or another interacts with bioethics law.

I would recommend this course. It is interesting, not difficult, and accessible. I had expected/hoped for more legal/ethical reasoning, but the course is more of an overview of various topics. For what it is though, the course does a good job, and I'm glad I took it.
Highly recommend for an interesting, low-work fifth class! Attending lecture was truly enjoyable and the readings were interesting but relatively optional.
Sure! If medicine and law interest you like they interest me, this class would be a good fit for you.
Take it - it's not difficult, not too much work, and very interesting.
It is interesting as an accessible intro to law-based classes. The bioethics is more like public health, not very technical. More political in focus than scientific.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone at Yale College because of how interesting and how timely the content is.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was very interesting and I learned a ton about things that may actually be relevant someday in my life.
Yes. If youre looking for basic insight into law, this is a great course.
yes! if you have any interest in the law or medicine or both, take bioethics!
I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone. The workload was extremely manageable and the material taught was so so interesting, relevant to our lives, and important to learn.

Yes! This is my favorite class I've taken at Yale. Professor Latham is an amazing lecturer that keeps you engaged and interested for the entire time. Section almost always consists of very interesting discussions. The assessments are fair and extremely doable. Also, it gave me a new and in depth perspective on  historic and modern bioethics/legal debates. Highly recommended.
Yes, I think this is important to know as we all deal with the health care system.
Yes I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it is genuinely interesting and I believe theyd enjoy going to class.

Absolutely! In order to get the most out of the course, you should make sure to read the casebook and do the Canvas readings, which are often quite considerable. But Professor Latham is great, and this course has taught me a lot.
Entirely dependent on your TA

I would definitely recommend this class to another student. Even if you are not a political science major, it is a great social science course. It is an extremely interesting class and the professor is great.
Yes if youre interested in the class, I would take it. Latham is a nice and knowledgeable Professor also.

yes! I absolutely love this course and recommended it to all of my friends. It is engaging, interesting, well taught, and not too much work. It was a great addition to my schedule this semester that put me at 5 credits without being overwhelming.
Yes, this is an amazing course. It is so interesting, and Latham is a great lecturer.
It is a very informative and fun class for anyone that enjoys the U.S healthcare system.

Please take this class! Prof. Latham is an amazing lecturer and the subject matter he covers is fascinating-- you'll learn about the ethics of organ procurement and transplantation and physician-assisted suicide among other topics. Grading is based on two midterms and a final, and outside of tests, the only work is a short weekly response to questions brought up during lecture (ungraded!) and section attendance. I've heard from past years that grading tends to be pretty variable from TA to TA, though this year tests were looked over by multiple TAs to standardize scores.

This class is super interesting, and Professor Latham is a great lecturer! It's not a lot of work, although it may be difficult to get an A depending on your TA. Nevertheless, it's definitely worth taking, and all of the topics are super relevant to today's world.
I would highly recommend this course! It is not too hard and is extremely interesting. Going to lecture is fun because you get to know about so many important and interesting issues and topics.

Yes! You'll learn a lot about important bioethical issues. However, these are "first world problems." This is not a class on global health, so many of the debates (e.g. gene editing, egg donation) are not relevant in most parts of the world. That being said, I think there still is a lot of value in taking the class. It's not just about learning about these issues. You will also learn to think in the way the US legal system approaches issues. Class itself is interesting, and we go into more of the nuances of various debates during section. Grading seems to depend on the TA a lot.
Yes. A must-take at Yale!
Yes! Chill and interesting - rare at Yale.

I would recommend to a student who likes law and bio and can write a good essay. It really depends on what TA you get so if you get a goody that doesn't hand out less than an A- well you will love this class.
Yes!! You learn so much and the professor is amazing at presenting the course material. I never get bored in this class.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is very interesting material that is very helpful to know. Most students do not know a lot about bioethics before taking this class.
This is a great course. Professor Latham is a very engaging lecturer, and his lectures are like listening to a story.
Yes, 100%. Professor Latham is an amazing lecturer and is so knowledgable. This course raises really interesting questions about bioethics.
15/10I would absolutely recommend this course to another student.

Yes! As has been said a thousand times before, Professor Latham is a truly outstanding lecturer. I am so glad I took this class, because the material was both fascinating and quite applicable to my own life. Section was also fulfilling, but that may have been just because I had a great TA.
Yes, it was super interesting! But don't expect it to be an easy A by any means. The midterms are tough and graded strictly.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. Bioethics is something that is that is relevant to everyone, whether personally or within the family, so it is interesting to know where the laws and precedents originate. More generally, it is interesting to see how and where the public Heath intersects with the legal system. It also covered a lot of different domains, so I think it would interest a wide variety of people.
Yes, but Credit/D/Fail. You might be surprised what omitting a couple things here and there in your essays can do to your grade.
Yes, its a good introductory law course!
yes

Definitely take this course! It's valuable for nearly everyone -- an understanding of how our healthcare system works, how the government enforces public health etc. is useful for all of us. For pre-meds especially, however, this may not be an official requirement but it's certainly one of the most important classes you can take as a pre-med. It's so important to understand the challenges facing modern medicine and science. Plus, the workload is very reasonable -- attending lecture/section and taking good notes is the key to this class, with the only other work being two midterms and a final. As long as you're present and engaged, this class won't be difficult!

This class is a great overview of a lot of historical and contemporary issues in bioethics. All the lectures are interesting and you learn a lot about the US medical system that mightve not otherwise been clear. Its also chill in terms of work load. The exams are obv not fun because you have to write essays in very short time spans and sections are pretty variable in quality (bc there are so many TAs) but Id still recommend it!

I would recommend this course to anyone, regardless of their major. Everyone dies, so they should know about physician-assisted suicide and end of life care. A large percentage of couples face infertility, so they should know about assisted reproduction. The material is fascinating and applicable to real life. The midterms were a lot more about regurgitating information, which I didn't like, but the final exam was a lot more about analyzing overarching themes.

I would highly recommend this course. Its really interesting and gets you thinking about your own opinions and positions on the issues. Also, its not super stressful so you can really just enjoy thinking about the topics.
I would definitely recommend this course. It's super fascinating.
Yes. Very well taught
Most definitely, it is very interesting and we have some great discussions during section.

I would recommend this class. Professor Latham is extremely well versed in the issues and does a great job explaining really complicated stuff quickly and in a way that is easy to understand. There's no real homework other than reading and the reading isn't necessary to your understanding of the material. You have to take two midterms and a final, but that's it. It's a great class if you want to learn about some really relevant, complicated stuff if a relatively relaxed setting. I left this class feeling like I actually understand a bunch of material that I hear about all the time and have not comprehension of. Take it, but maybe take it Credit/D and switch at the midterm.
This is the best course I have taken at Yale. The workload isn't bad (2 midterms and a cumulative final exam), but the material is well-taught and the course is so engaging.

Take this class!! Even if you're not in a field related to bioethics or law, the course presents some really interesting and practical real-world topics. You'll get an overview of the US healthcare system as well as learn about important cases in the realms of organ donation, end of life care, genetics, abortion, human subjects research, etc. The readings aren't necessary to get a good grade in the class, but I took the class Credit/D and ended up reading all the cases anyways since they were so interesting. Theres very little work (just 3 exams), and Prof. Latham goes at a very reasonable pace in lecture, to the point that you learn a lot without getting bored.
Yes wonderful

Absolutely take this course. I recommend taking it Cr/D/Fail, because you can really enjoy the lectures without feeling like you have to take notes or do readings. I found that because I wasn't concerned about my grade, I was able to engage more with the ethics and philosophy of the course rather than getting hung up on the law and court cases (which I was less interested in).
Definitely! It is important to be well informed about bioethical issues if you are interested in medicine, law, public health, or just want to be a knowledgeable citizen.

I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in t topics about the controversies and issues about the American healthcare system and bioethical issues related to it. Not a difficult yet interesting class.
It is a very interesting survey course - so yes! But if you are looking for a challenging course on the law, there are other options.

YES! I am not a polysci, stem, or anything related to this course kind of person but I LOVED the material (abortion, end of life care, physician assisted suicide, public health law, etc.). I just feel like they're such important topics to know about in terms of current events and politics. The class itself was also fairly easy -- I never read the textbook besides the few cases I had to read for section (which on average required like 5 pages of reading and a short response). I did take really detailed notes in lecture though which helped a lot, def think this is more of a lecture > textbook class if you had to choose one. The exams were fair but required a decent amount of studying and some memorization (though you don't need to know case names). It's definitely a great credit D class or you can easily get a B+ to A range with minimal effort. Overall, easy AND interesting class that's very worthwhile. It had literally nothing to do with what I study but it's just one of those great Yale classes you should take anyways, and Prof. Latham is incredible!
YES!

I would definitely recommend this class to any student looking to get a broad overview of the debates and legal framework relevant to bioethics.  This class is not for someone who already knows a lot about bioethics.  However, for those who don't know much about the topic, this was an amazing introductory class.  The professor was also really clear and easy to understand, and the workload and exams were extremely reasonable.
Absolutely. Incredibly informative and interesting.

Yes! I took it credit/d as a fifth class and it was perfect. Lectures are super engaging because Latham is great. Material is easy to grasp and sections are basically a review of the material, so it's super helpful and useful (since it's mandatory).
Definitely. Interesting material and good social science credit.
Yes, this class was extremely interesting and I can honestly say that I learned a lot that I hope to retain into the future.
Yes, it's a straightforward class with a lot of interesting information.

Yes! Highly recommended as a 5th class, or as a regular part of your schedule if you decide to commit to the readings. Most of the cases in the book are interesting to read, however I only read the important ones which my TF starred, which I recommend you do as well. Besides that, much of the reading is unnecessary because Latham covers it all in lecture. If you go to lecture, it is interesting and easy to pay attention and take notes. I think this is probably a gut, but definitely a gut you must go to lecture and pay attention to if you want to get an A or even an A- because the midterms and final are the only things that make up you final grade. I highly recommend this class.
Yes, this class is great. I enjoyed it a lot as a biology major, but I can also see why it would be interesting to anyone who has an interest in the law as well.
This is a great course to start thinking about the medical issues that we might face as we enter the real world, such as denying end-of-life care and using artificial reproduction techniques.

You MUST take this class. You are missing out if you do not take it. You should have serious fomo if you don't take this class. It is worth it. The lectures are incredible and fascinating. So engaging. Never a dull moment. The topics are so relevant to the world. Every major will benefit from this class.
Definitely. This is an incredibly interesting field and one that is very relevant in society.
I would definitely recommend this class.  It was easily the best ratio of interesting material to workload of any class I've taken so far at Yale.
Yes; very interesting. Large amount of real-world application.
Yes take this class, you'll learn a lot.

Yes!! This course was amazing. I learned so much about the US healthcare system (as well as foreign countries) and general medical/business knowledge. The best part of the class was section - the discussions were really interesting, especially because we had so many different points of view at the table.
yes

I would definitely recommend the course to another student, if only for the lectures, which were spectacular.  Professor Latham is an amazing speaker, and his lectures were always so well-put-together (all the more impressive because he didn't seem to refer to any notes).  My discussion section was a little disappointing -- I wanted to be challenged more in our discussions, but they were rather lukewarm.  Still, simply because of the lectures, I learned a lot on a subject that is increasingly important as technology advances and our political situation (d)evolves.
Yes it was very interesting and I learend a lot.

Its a really good classvery well taught. You should definitely take it if you have even a passing interest in bioethics. The tests arent badjust remember the cases and one they relate to each other in building up public health law and youll be fine. The lectures are really interesting as well so dont skip.
Absolutely take this. If you don't take it, you're playing yourself.

YES. Take this class. Honestly, the material is so interesting, and Latham is a star. It isn't as gutty as some make it out to be, but just take really good notes and attend class (no need to read the book really) and you should be fine.
Yes, it is super interesting and you learn new things and new ways of looking at legal issues within the medical field. The professor really knows how to keep students attention.
You better either show up to class or do the readings, otherwise you're screwed. Also pray you get a good TA. Can be a great class, but have also heard it can be traumatic.
Great professor, so yes.
Yes!!! Issues discussed in bioethics are so relevant to our current world and in relationship to developing technology.
Absolutely! The class is really interesting, the TF's were all great, the workload is manageable, definitely a must take!
Yes very interesting material and engaging lectures.
Yes, it has very important information.
yes
